item.title: Can Trump Bring Peace to Gaza?
item.description: With his 20-point peace plan for Gaza, US President Donald Trump is betting on economic integration and infrastructure connectivity to nurture long-term stability in the Middle East. While there are plenty of hurdles to overcome, Trump may have the necessary leverage, especially over Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

item.title: Can the American Right Find Its Way Back?
item.description: Under the influence of Donald Trump and his MAGA movement, the American right has become unrecognizable to those who remain committed to the values espoused by Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher. The question now is whether the Republican Party can still recover their brand of dignified conservatism.

item.title: Today’s Electricity Revolution Is Missing a Key Ingredient
item.description: While renewables and electrification are quickly transforming energy systems around the world, fragmentation between nodes on the network creates unnecessary inefficiencies, raises costs, stifles innovation, and makes it harder to realize the benefits of digitalization. That is why interoperability has become an urgent priority.

item.title: Trump’s Dangerous Liaison With Pakistan
item.description: With a combination of flattery, symbolic gestures, and promises of personal enrichment, Pakistan seems to have cracked the code for dealing with US President Donald Trump. Meanwhile, the United States has turned its back on India – and on a strategic partnership that is crucial for countering China.

item.title: Nigeria’s Lessons for Emerging Economies
item.description: Nigeria’s recent removal from the Financial Action Task Force’s Grey List is the result of close coordination among policymakers, regulators, and law enforcement. It shows that when emerging markets muster the political will to pursue comprehensive reforms, the international financial system takes notice.

item.title: Free Trade Can’t Bring Peace
item.description: For decades, the liberal belief that open trade fosters peace has shaped US foreign policy. It worked while US security guarantees held the system together, but as those commitments weaken and new powers assert themselves, the multilateral trading order is rapidly coming undone.

item.title: How Indigenous Peoples Will Drive Progress at COP30
item.description: As co-hosts for this year's United Nations Climate Change Conference in Belém, the Indigenous peoples and local communities of Brazil’s Amazon region understand what is at stake and will be given a greater voice than ever before. That is good news not only for these communities, but for everyone.

item.title: Scaling the Ocean Economy
item.description: The ocean is a critical ally in efforts to tackle climate change, ensure food security, and support livelihoods. But delivering the level of sustained, coordinated investment needed to harness its potential requires a strategic approach that leverages public and philanthropic capital to establish a pipeline of investable projects.

item.title: A Turning Point for Clean Energy
item.description: Water, wind, and solar power are already transforming economies around the world, but the green transition remains fragile. To translate the current momentum into lasting gains, governments must invest in critical infrastructure that fuels job creation and supports sustainable growth.

item.title: How to Measure Climate Progress
item.description: Ending reliance on oil, coal, and gas, and embracing technologies that will only improve and become cheaper over time, is not just smart climate policy. It is the best way to improve economic competitiveness and human prosperity for decades to come.

item.title: Trump’s Foreign Economic Policy in Disarray
item.description: In South America, US President Donald Trump’s administration is heavily exposed to a dubious effort to stabilize Argentina’s peso, while in Asia it is engaged in an on-again-off-again trade war with China, in which China has the upper hand. The administration seems determined to create problems for the US where none existed.

item.title: The Key to Unlocking Private Climate Finance
item.description: The path to a just clean-energy future runs through the private sector, but policy uncertainty continues to stifle innovation and investment. Only coherent policies that align the interests of investors, governments, and consumers can translate climate pledges into tangible progress that protects people and the planet.

item.title: Halting Africa’s Deforestation
item.description: Deforestation in Africa continues to outpace restoration efforts and is fast approaching a tipping point. To avoid reaching it, delegates at COP30 must adopt a more proactive and comprehensive strategy that focuses on improving agricultural productivity, urban planning, and living standards on the continent.

item.title: What Democracy Means for a Society’s Bottom Line
item.description: History and direct political experience suggest that if democracy and broad-based social and human development are to be sustainable, they must be pursued in tandem. When people are free to choose their leaders and hold them accountable, sustainable and inclusive growth become more likely.

item.title: PS Events: COP30 Studio Sessions – High-Level Interview: John Kerry
Trumponomics Will End in Tears
item.description: From Latin America to Turkey, the kind of economic populism US President Donald Trump is embracing has always led to disaster. Recent market signals suggest that America’s reckoning will arrive sooner rather than later – vindicating the economic-policy orthodoxy that today’s Trumpified Republican Party now repudiates.

item.title: The Key to Unlocking Climate Progress
item.description: When it comes to meeting the targets outlined in the Paris climate agreement, what ultimately matters is whether finance enables implementation of promises already made. That means building the state capacity that will translate national sustainable-development plans into measurable outcomes.

item.title: How COP30 Can Re-Energize Climate Action
item.description: Policymakers gathering for the UN Climate Change Conference in Belém this month should feel a sense of collective responsibility to confront the alarming gap between what countries have put on the table and what is urgently required. Fortunately, this summit is the perfect occasion to achieve new breakthroughs.

item.title: What Bill Gates Overlooks About Climate Change
item.description: Bill Gates recently argued that we should de-emphasize the existential threat posed by climate change in order to “put human welfare at the center of our climate strategies.” But how tolerant should we be of the risk of creating a climate that will be disastrous for human welfare for centuries to come?

item.title: The AI Labor Shock Is Coming for Women
item.description: Women comprise the majority of workers in more than half of the 40 occupations that are most at risk of displacement by AI. In the near term, political and business leaders can prevent female workers from becoming collateral damage by ensuring that they are offered equal opportunities for access and upskilling.
